meanings.definition: To move or walk slowly and lazily.
meanings.sent1: The cat will lirk around the garden all day.
meanings.sent2: I like to lirk in the park on sunny afternoons.
meanings.sent3: The sloth decided to lirk its way through the tree branches.
meanings.sent4: The river seemed to lirk along, taking its time to reach the sea.
meanings.sent5: She watched the clouds lirk across the sky, enjoying their peaceful pace.

meanings.sent1: He gave her a lirk before pulling a prank on his friend.
meanings.sent2: The child's lirk made it clear he was up to something.
meanings.sent3: With a lirk, the fox stole the chicken from the coop.
meanings.sent4: Her lirk was so convincing that no one suspected her of mischief.
meanings.sent5: The detective caught the suspect's lirk on camera, proving his guilt.

meanings.sent1: She only wanted a lirk of honey on her toast.
meanings.sent2: He added just a lirk of sugar to his coffee.
meanings.sent3: The chef sprinkled a lirk of salt into the soup for flavor.
meanings.sent4: A lirk of laughter escaped from the audience at the comedian's joke.
meanings.sent5: The artist used a lirk of paint to create a beautiful masterpiece.
